item.title: Tips & Tricks
item.description: Some advice just couldn’t be placed anywhere without seeming out of place or making things unnecessarily complicated. This chapter provides a list of leftover guidelines, rules and tips.

item.title: Verbs: infinitives
item.description: I mentioned the infinitive right at the start of the verb chapters. It’s how you find verbs in the dictionary.

item.title: Verbs: passive voice
item.description: All sentences, examples, and tutorials so far have been active voice. I recommend using that whenever you can. Because it’s shorter, simpler and more direct.

item.title: Adjectives
item.description: Well done! You have learned all about the two basic blocks of English language: nouns and verbs. You should be able to read and write any basic sentence—with any time or intention.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: I hope you enjoyed this course. I hope it gave insight into the magical world of typography. With the tools and ideas I’ve given to you, I hope you’re able to start your next design confidently and pick the most awesome fonts and parameters.

item.title: Data Manipulation II
item.description: In the Strings chapter, I promised some more “bag-like” operations to do on strings. They can be extremely important or not important at all, depending on your project.

item.title: Multiple Columns
item.description: Columns aren’t natively supported by LaTeX. I know, that strange typesetting language keeps throwing curveballs. But they are easily included with the help of the package multicol.

item.title: Proportions
item.description: Proportion is a way of expressing how the magnitude of an element relates to that of another element. This could be the length of a line compared to the length of another line, or the scale of a square compared to another square, or the height of a circle compared to the height of a square.

item.title: Texture
item.description: With great lines and shading, you can now draw amazing objects. But only if they are smooth and solid!

item.title: Adverbs
item.description: Adverbs are the wildcard of any language. They can be formed out of anything and applied to nearly everything.

item.title: Hyperlinks & URLs
item.description: At the time TeX was introduced, hyperlinks and URLs weren’t as mainstream as they are now. That’s why any support for these has to come from a nifty little package called hyperref.

item.title: Space
item.description: I intentionally left out any remarks about space in the previous chapter. People often forget the importance of space, even though it has many important applications.

item.title: Studies & Reference
item.description: I’ve shown you how to construct anything out of basic shapes and forms. I’ve shown you how to add realism and enrichment to your drawings.

item.title: Where to go now?
item.description: Well done! You’ve read and worked through the whole course. The hard part is over. Why? Because any language you’ll use in the future will have the things I mentioned.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: This concludes the course about learning to code. Hopefully, I was able to ignite a spark. That’s why I learned to code, so long ago.

item.title: Determiners
item.description: You’ve mastered the basics of English language … almost. Only two more chapters. This one will talk about the many simple but crucial words for making everything work.

item.title: Figures & Images
item.description: We’ve already seen the table environment. It does nothing more than contain a table and any metadata, such as a caption or reference.

item.title: Symmetry
item.description: The strongest principle of graphic design is balance, as it encompasses all the other principles. Balance and hierarchy, the magical duo of graphic design!

item.title: The Right Mind-Set I
item.description: Many people think they can’t draw. Or maybe they remember being awesome at drawing when they were young, but never draw anymore because they’re afraid to disappoint themselves.

item.title: Cheat Sheet
item.description: Use the image below to quickly remind yourself of the basic grammar rules. In case you are in doubt or forgot something.

item.title: Conjunctions & Compounds
item.description: This course taught you all the small, individual pieces that make up a language. You’ve also seen ways to combine and modify them: using prepositions, adverbs, pronouns.

item.title: Special Pages I
item.description: We’ve already briefly seen the title page and table of contents at the start of every document. But there are more special pages that are usually included in LaTeX documents.

item.title: Tension & Motion
item.description: These principles, tension and motion, have popped frequently throughout this course. They aren’t a necessary principle or element for a design to work, but they are often what makes a design dynamic and makes us feel like it comes to life.

item.title: The Right Mind-Set II
item.description: To make matters clear, and those statements from last chapter more concrete, I’ll provide you with a list of very useful guidelines.

item.title: Clock & Dates
item.description: Denoting time is one of the oldest functions of a language. You know what that means by now: irregularity.

item.title: Framing
item.description: In the chapter on proportions, I already stated the size of the media you use plays an important role.

item.title: Imagination & Creativity
item.description: Most of this course has been rules and guidelines which are generally best to follow. This means all your drawings might look quite alike.

item.title: Special Pages II
item.description: Continuing on last chapter, here are the two other quite important special pages. The main purpose of LaTeX was to easily write clear and beautiful (scientific) papers or lasting documents for global consumption.

item.title: Abstraction
item.description: This course talked about mimicking the real world, quite often. Designs are appealing and clear, if they use human nature and physical principles we understand, instead of working against it.

item.title: Common Mistakes
item.description: In this course, I’ve often left remarks about the best way to write things. I find this important. Language is about communication, so let’s see how to improve that communication as much as possible.

item.title: Conclusion: what now?
item.description: You’ve learnt everything! You are the Master of Drawing! Nah, I’m just kidding, of course. You’ve learnt all the fundamentals of drawing and probably a bit more than that.

item.title: Pages Layouts & Margin
item.description: Until now we’ve silently accepted the size of the margins LaTeX decides. Not anymore! Let’s look changing the amount of white space around your document.

item.title: Composition
item.description: Hopefully you noticed that this course moved from the smallest possible pieces towards the biggest. We started with basic elements (point, line, shape) Then continued with principles applicable to groups of elements And principles about larger areas or the whole general design And now we’re at the chapter that’s about the end product of every design: a composition.

item.title: Conclusion: what now?
item.description: Congratulations! You’re a LaTeX wizard now ✨ You’ve seen and played with the fundamentals of LaTeX. Even some slightly advanced topics.

item.title: Conclusion: what now?
item.description: Pfew, that was a long course. I don’t think any more can be said about graphic design. I also understand it might have been technical or theoretical at many points.
